Dorset-square; I told a watchman, and we followed him - he went to Boston-place instead of Boston-street; we stopped him at the door, and marked the boards - he gave me Pitts' direction; I went, and could find no such person; I returned, and told the watchman; we then went to his house, and took him and the boards; he then said the man he had them of lived in Brownlow-street, Seven-dials. I went there, and found one Pitt.

THOMAS GRANT
. I am a watchman, and took the prisoner and the deals. I had put a broad-arrow on them.

JAMES REDWOOD
. I am in Mr. Hall's employ. I missed these deals from the passage of this house; I nailed the door up the Monday before; I found it forced open; these are the boards.

HUMPHREY ROBERTS
. I went to the prisoner's house with the witnesses, and found the deals in the passage - he said they belonged to him - that he had them from Mr. Pitts, of Kilburn, and afterwards said Brownlow-street - I am certain of it.
Prisoner's Defence. I buy boards of different persons.

RICHARD PITT
. I live in Brownlow-street, and am a metal dealer, and deal in wood; I did not sell the prisoner this deal; I have a carpenter on my premises in Portland town - I cannot say that he did not sell them; the prisoner is a tinman, but he is builing a house; my carpenter should tell me when he sells wood.
WM. PRIEST. The prisoner was a quarter of a mile beyond Mr. Pitts' premises, coming towards them.
GUILTY. Aged 38.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

747.
ANN KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15thof February , 1 pair of boots, value 3s. 6d. , the goods of
John Lofts
.

HANNAH LOFTS
. I am wife of John Lofts; we live in Turk's-row, Chelsea
. These boots lay on a box by the fire-place - I met the prisoner (who is a stranger) in Jews'-row, between eleven and twelve o'clock, on the 15th - we got into conversation; she said she could help me to two or three days' work every week, and she would go home with me, that she might know where to send for me; we went into my room; and as I turned my back to bid a neighbour good bye, she must have concealed the boots; she went away - I went out, and returned at half-past seven o'clock; I then missed them - I am sure they were there when she was in the room - nobody else was there - I locked my door when I went out, and found it still locked - I never allowed her to take them.

JOHN KILLINGSWORTH
. I am servant to Mr. Perkins, pawnbroker. On the 15th of February, between twelve and four o'clock, the prisoner pawned these boots for 2s. - I knew her before - Mrs. Loft claimed them that night.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM ALLEN
. I took her in charge.
Prisoner. I leave it to your mercy.
GUILTY. Aged 42.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

748.
JANE HOWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 blanket, value 4s., and 1 saucepan, value 3s., the goods of
Charlotte Ann Ward
, widow , in a lodging-room .

CHARLOTTE ANN WARD. I live in St. Ann-street, Westminster. On the 10th of February the prisoner took a lodging at my house, which is in St. John the Evangelist, Westminster
; she had the first floor front room, furnished; she represented herself as a married woman - I did not see her husband till next day - I have since heard she is not married; she was to pay 4s. 3d. a week; she staid till the Tuesday night, when she was apprehended on another charge, and I missed this property, which was let with the room - I never gave her leave to pawn them.

DELMOUR WADE
. My mother keeps a general dealer's shop in St. Andrew-street. On the 12th of February, about nine o'clock in the morning, the prisoner sold us a large iron saucepan for 14d., and we have sold it again - I am certain she is the woman; Harris, the pawnbroker, of Tothill-street, has the property, but will not attend.

BENJAMIN TIMBRELL
. I am an officer. I have the property which Harris delivered to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)

LOUISA STEPHENSON
. I heard the prisoner acknowledge that this property was the prosecutrix's.
Prisoner's Defence. I beg for mercy - my friends are too respectable to let them know of my situation.
GUILTY Aged 40.
Confined Two Months .

749.
FREDERICK HOBBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of January , 1 jar, value 1s., and 15 lbs. of honey, value 16s. , the goods of
William Liddell
.

The facts of this case are fully stated in the trial of
Richard Koesell
, and others (see page 249), the prisoner was too much indisposed to take his trial with them.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

750.
PAGE DONALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , at the precinet of St. Katherine, 12 sovereigns, the monies of
David Livingstone
, in the dwelling-house of
Joseph Wilson
.

ELIZABETH WILSON
. I am wife of Joseph Wilson, who is a watchman. We rent a house, No. 9, Phoenix-court, Butcher-row, in the precint of St. Katherine's
. David Livingstone lodged in our house. On the 13th of February he complained to me of having lost some money; he slept in our top room with the prisoner. Livingstone is agent to his son, who is a manufacturer at Dundee.

DAVID LIVINGSTONE. I lodge at Mr. Wilson's. The prisoner slept in the same room; I have been there thirteen weeks - he was there before me; I had my money in my chest, which was locked, and stood in that room - I put twelve sovereigns in there on Saturday, the 10th of February, in the foot of a stocking, and missed them on Monday, the 12th - all the twelve sovereigns were gone; another man, named
Joseph Harrison
, lodged in the room- he still remains there; the prisoner and him slept in one bed; I slept in another in the same room - I am sure I locked my chest on Saturday when I put my money in, and on Sunday I took out a shirt, and locked the chest again - I found the lock on Monday as I left it - it had not been opened by any violence, but must have been opened by a false key; I am sure I had not left my own key in the room; I was fearful of bringing reproach on the house, and did not fetch a constable for a day or two, but the prisoner kept spending money - he was taken up on the Friday or Saturday, and was then quite drunk - he remained in the house till then.
E. WILSON re-examined. Livingstone did not mention his loss to me till the 13th - I told the prisoner, if he had the money he had better say so, and give it up - this was on the morning of the 13th.

WILLIAM STOWELL
. I am a publican. On Thursday last, 15th of Feb., between 6 and 7 o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came to my house with two other men - they had some beer - one of the men went out with the prisoner, and then they came in again - the prisoner had used the house before, and I knew him; he came to the bar, and said to me, "I have saved up a little money - will you take care of it for me?" and gave me nine sovereigns - they were not in any thing; he came on Friday morning, and had one back - he came again on Saturday, and had one from my wife - I produced the other seven.

THOMAS OBORNE
. I am night-beadle of Aldgate. I took the prisoner into custody on Saturday, and asked how he came by the nine sovereigns - I held out no promise or threat - his answer was, he supposed he had stolen them - I might take him to the Police-office, or do what I pleased with him - I heard him say at the office that he found them in the room where he lodged.

Prisoner to LIVINGSTONE. Q. Was there any silver with your sovereigns? A. I do not know, but think there was twelve sovereigns and 20s. together, wrapped in paper, and put into a stocking; here is the paper they were in - I know it by some figures, and it was given me by Mrs. Wilson, who found it in the room.
Prisoner. I own I picked up the money under my my feet in the room - there were ten sovereigns, two half-sovereigns, and 19s.

MR. WILSON. He lived with us twelve months lastAugust - I considered him an honest man - we do not take in nightly lodgers; nobody but Livingstone, the prisoner, and Harrison, slept in that room - Harrison still lodges with us.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 34.
Recommended to Mercy, on account of his character .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

751.
THOMAS WOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 12 pigs, price 12l. , the property of
George Tucker
.

GEORGE TUCKER. I am a coachmaker , and live at Ponder's-end
. On Monday the 13th of February, I missed twelve pigs which were safe the night before in my stye; I traced them a short way, and then left the officer to trace them; the prisoner lived near me, and knew my premises well; they were worth 12l.; three were fit to kill; one was a large store pig; three of them weighed about five stone each.

EDWARD DRAKE
. I live at Redstile, about seven miles from Tucker. On Monday, the 13th, at half past five o'clock in the morning, I was near my own house, and met the prisoner with ten or twelve pigs, some large and some small; one was very small, and had a white spot on the left side, near the hind part; I have known the prisoner nine years, and am certain of his person; the fattest would weigh four or five stone, I think the small one about two stone; he was going towards Colneyhatch, and another man walking by his side, but the prisoner drove them with a stick or whip; I should not have noticed them if the prisoner had not spoken to me; he said, "Hold on one side, master, and let my pigs come by;" I was not in the road; I said I will; he said, "Oh, is that you, Ned?" he always goes by the name of Tom Ponto; I never heard him called Wood; I asked him if he was going to take them to Smithfield; he said "Aye" I asked if pigs were dear or cheap; he said dear.

JOHN WILSON
. I am constable of Enfield. Mr. Tucker told me of his loss; I traced the pigs to Colney-hatch; they had been fed upon frosty potatoes, which scowered them, and that is how I traced them; I traced them about a mile from the yard down a bye lane, beyond where Drake met the prisoner, and there I lost the traces.

THOMAS REEVES
. I am a patrol. On Thursday night last, a butcher gave the prisoner into my charge; he asked me if it was about Walker's horse; (see page 216) I said No, about the pigs; he said "D-n the pigs."
GEORGE TUCKER. I had fed the pigs on potatoes, beans, and peas - one small one had a white spot, and was about two stone weight.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a young man driving the pigs, and walked about a quarter of a mile with him; there were nine of them.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

752.
DENNIS MANNICKS
and CATHERINE, his wife
, were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Dowding
, in the forenoon of the 10th of February , (he and others being therein) and stealing 6 shirts, value 3s.; 2 shifts, value 3s.; 4 sheets, value 10s.; 2 pairs of stays, value 5s.; 1 frock, value 2s.; 2 blankets, value 4s.; 5 pin-cloths, value 5s.; 1 shawl, value 5s., and 1 towel, value 6d. , his property.

GEORGE DOWDING. I live in Long-acre
. On the 10th of February, at half-past nine in the morning, I went into my kitchen, and found the door broken open; I have lodgers in my house; it is an inner door, and had been locked, and there are the marks of a chisel on it; I went in, and missed this property, and much more; my wife had them to mangle; the prisoners are strangers, and had no business in the house; I gave information, and on the 15th went with an officer to the prisoners' room, and found a frock, a firelock, and a towel.

GEORGE McKEE
. I apprehended the prisoners on another charge, and found some duplicates, with their names on them, on their premises; I cannot say they lived there - it is in Steward's-rents.

ROBERT YOUNG
. I am shopman to Messrs. Townsend and Co., pawnbroker. I have some child's clothes, pawned by the female prisoner, in her own name, and other articles, pawned by one Kelly.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM WOOTTEN
. I went to Steward's-rents; the furniture was moved out, and I found some property in a cellar.
NOT GUILTY .

753.
JEREMIAH CONNOR
was indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Horncastle
, about the hour of eight, in the night of the 10th of February , at St. Botolph without, Aldgate, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 3 shirts, value 6s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 3s.; 2 caps, value 6s.; 1 frill, value 2s., and 1 gown, value 1s. , the goods of the said Elizabeth Horncastle.

ELIZABETH HORNCASTLE. I am single , and live in Greenwood's-court, Nightingale-lane, in the parish of St. Botolph without, Aldgate
- I have one room below and one up-stairs - the landlord does not live in the house. On Saturday night, the 10th of February, I went out, and locked the door of my lower room, just as the London-dock bell was going eight o'clock - I put the key into my pocket, and was gone about five minutes; the street-door has a single lock - I shut the street door - when I returned, I found my lower room door unlocked - I believe it had been opened by a key; I lost the property stated in the indictment; the officer has a shirt and a gown, which were picked up; there was a skeleton-key picked up in the court by a young woman the same evening, and I found one next door but one to my house, in the court, next morning; some caps were taken out of a trunk, and put on a table; the other articles were taken from a chest.

MARY BROWN
. I am the wife of
George Brown
; we occupy a room in this house, on the first floor;
Charles Ruby
lives with me. I went out on this night, at half-past seven o'clock, and staid about half an hour; when I came back, I found the street door, which I had shut, was open, and Horncastle's door too; I had left Horncastle at home; when I came home, and was going in, the prisoner and another man rushed out by me, from out of Horncastle's room; the prisoner struck me in the breast; it was merely a push to get out of the way; I had a viewof his face, as there was a candle on the table, in Horncastle's room; I am sure he is the man; Ruby, who was with me, followed him, and brought him back in a few minutes; I did not see that he had any thing; when he came out, I went in; and when he was brought back he said, "Let me go;" when he got to the watch-house he said to us."You are the right sort; do your best, and do your worst."

CHARLES RUBY. I am a coal-porter, and lodge in this house. I went out with Mrs. Brown, about half-past seven o'clock, and believe she shut the door; we returned in about half an hour; I was close behind her; she went in first; the prisoner rushed out, gave her a shove in the breast, and another rushed out at the same time; I pursued the prisoner close, and caught him without losing sight of him, near the end of Redcross-street; when he came back he said, "Let me go;" I said I should take him to the watch-house; the patrol came, and took him; there were good gas-lights in the street, all the way; I passed some clothes, which were dropped in the way; I ran, and called out, "Pick them up;" as I still followed him.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not say, at the office, that a sailor stopped me? A. No; he is the man, who ran out of the house; whom I followed and took.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am a patrol. I was in Nightingale-lane, and ran, hearing a cry of Stop thief! when I came near to the workhouse a man said, "Here is a shirt, which one of them has dropped;" he gave it me, and I picked up this gown; I then assisted Ruby in taking the prisoner to the watch-house, and delivered the property to Oborne.

THOMAS OBORNE
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house with this gown and shawl; I searched him, but found nothing on him.

MARY FOSTER
. I live two doors from Horncastle, in the same court - I found this skeleton-key, about an hour after the robbery; it was by the next house.
CHARLES RUBY. That was in the way he ran.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. When I was taken, the woman said she thought I was the young man who used to call to see Betsey; but at the watch-house she said, "No, it is not him."

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21.
